scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Climate
scientific_phenomena.description: Much of the northern part of the continent has a cold climate and harsh environment. STRUGGLING READERS Population Density 1. To illustrate and to help students understand population density, draw several equal-sized squares on the board and label each “1 square mile.

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Ecosystem
scientific_phenomena.description: Coastal ecosystems are being pressured by urban develop- ment. The demand for fresh water also increases with population. Some countries may even face shortages in the future.
observation_prompts: What features of ecosystem can you identify in The Human World?
How might ecosystem affect people living in The Human World?
What patterns do you notice about ecosystem in The Human World?

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Ecosystem
scientific_phenomena.description: Water pollution damages fragile ecosystems. Consider ways people can POSITIVELY impact the environment: •Reforestation efforts restore ecological balance.

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World River
scientific_phenomena.description: For exa mple, farmers might build dams to prevent rivers from flooding and destroying their crops. Other factors such as belief systems, political decisions, and economic factors can influence technology use, too. Some religious groups, like the Amish people of the United States, selectively use technology.

How might river affect people living in The Human World?

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Mountain
scientific_phenomena.description: These areas may have rugged mountains or harsh deserts where people cannot grow crops. Some areas may be frozen all year long, making survival there very difficult. For these reasons, very few people live in parts of far North America, Greenland, northern Asia, and Australia.
observation_prompts: What features of mountain can you identify in The Human World?
How might mountain affect people living in The Human World?
What patterns do you notice about mountain in The Human World?

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Mountain
scientific_phenomena.description: Areas like deserts, mountains, or the Arctic do not have high population densities because the geography is too harsh to support human settlement. It is difficult to grow crops in deserts, along mountainsides, or in icy areas, so people choose not to live there.
observation_prompts: What features of mountain can you identify in The Human World?
How might mountain affect people living in The Human World?
What patterns do you notice about mountain in The Human World?

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Weather
scientific_phenomena.description: Natural Hazards Weather can be harsh and sometimes deadly. People can adapt to their environment by preparing for natural hazards such as fires, tornadoes, earthquakes, and hurricanes. They change what they do to stay safe based on the climate.
observation_prompts: What features of weather can you identify in The Human World?
How might weather affect people living in The Human World?
What patterns do you notice about weather in The Human World?

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Weather
scientific_phenomena.description: Depending o n the weather in a location, some schools have tornado drills or earthquake drills. Cities also have building codes for new buildings and structures . These codes are rules that tell what must be done to keep a building safe when people use it.
observation_prompts: What features of weather can you identify in The Human World?
How might weather affect people living in The Human World?
What patterns do you notice about weather in The Human World?

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Environment
scientific_phenomena.description: Point out that geographers study population and settlement patterns—where people live, how many people live there, and the effects those people have on the environment. Geographers track population changes and settlement patterns and study the reasons for those changes. Encourage students to keep the Essential Question in mind as they work through the module.

scientific_phenomena.title: The Human World Desert
scientific_phenomena.description: For example, the desert environment of Africa’s Sahara influences the w ay people who live there earn a living. Rather than grow crops, they herd ani- mals that have adapted to the harsh environment. As you can see, history and the environment affect how cultures develop.

writing_prompts: Using information from the passage and your own knowledge, write an informative paragraph about The Human World. Include at least three vocabulary terms from Part 1.
Describe an important geographic feature of The Human World and explain its significance to the region.
Compare and contrast two aspects of The Human World discussed in the reading passage.
reflection_questions: What new information did you learn about The Human World?
What questions do you still have about The Human World?
How does learning about The Human World help you understand our world better?
How might life in The Human World be similar to or different from your own?
